content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.Malaria is a disease that is caused by the eukaryotic parasite Plasmodium and is transmitted between individuals by the bite of infected mosquitoes. Different species of Plasmodium cause disease in different vertebrate species, but in all cases the parasite infects and destroys red blood cells. The repeated emergence of drug-resistant strains of Plasmodium parasites responsible for human infections has caused researchers to continually search for new drugs or combinations of drugs that can provide an effective treatment. A drug that has proven effective in recent years is artesunate, but now artesunate-resistant Plasmodium strains have also appeared.Researchers investigated whether artesunate-resistant Plasmodium strains could be effectively treated by other drugs. In a mouse model of malaria, the researchers determined that a particular strain of artesunate-sensitive Plasmodium (<math alttext="A R T S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) could be largely eliminated from the mice at a dose of 0.15 <math alttext="milligram per kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mg/kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. By repeated exposure of the artesunate-sensitive strain <math alttext="A R T S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to increasing concentrations of artesunate, the researchers developed a Plasmodium strain that is highly resistant to artesunate (<math alttext="A R T R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and requires a minimum dose of 240 <math alttext="milligrams per kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mg/kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to eliminate the parasites.The researchers then compared how effectively several common antimalarial drugs eliminate the <math alttext="A R T S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="A R T R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strains in vitro. The researchers infected human red blood cells with the <math alttext="A R T S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="A R T R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Plasmodium strains and incubated the infected cells in tissue culture medium. They added serial dilutions of the drugs to replicate cultures and determined the <math alttext="I C 50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IC50</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for each drug, the concentration of the drug that reduced the parasite load in the red blood cells by 50% (Table 1).Table 1. <math alttext="I C 50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IC50</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for common antimalarial drugs tested on artesunate-sensitive (<math alttext="A R T S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and artesunate-resistant (<math alttext="A R T R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) Plasmodium strainsDrug <math alttext="A R T S, I C 50, plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S: IC50</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="nanomolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>nM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) <math alttext="A R T R, I C 50, plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R: IC50</mtext><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="nanomolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>nM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) Amodiaquine 11.3 (0.8) 132.4 (16.9) Chloroquine 50.1 (3.6) 53.0 (11.3) DHA 13.8 (0.7) 49.5 (6.8) Mefloquine 41.7 (2.7) 39.1 (5.4) Quinine 49.7 (3.1) 216.9 (81) (a) Plasmodium is an organism with both sexual and asexual life cycles. Describe the most likely cause of a heritable phenotypic change in some members of a population of asexually reproducing organisms. Explain how repeated exposure of the artesunate-sensitive Plasmodium strain to increasing concentrations of artesunate led to the development of the artesunate-resistant Plasmodium strain.

41.7 (2.7) 39.1 (5.4) Quinine 49.7 (3.1) 216.9 (81) (a) Plasmodium is an organism with both sexual and asexual life cycles. Describe the most likely cause of a heritable phenotypic change in some members of a population of asexually reproducing organisms. Explain how repeated exposure of the artesunate-sensitive Plasmodium strain to increasing concentrations of artesunate led to the development of the artesunate-resistant Plasmodium strain.

(b) Using the template, construct an appropriately labeled graph to represent the data in Table 1. Based on the data, determine the antimalarial drugs that are likely to be significantly less effective at treating disease caused by the <math alttext="A R T R"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strain than by the <math alttext="A R T S"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strain.

(c) Based on the data, identify the drug that, from the <math alttext="A R T S"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strain to the <math alttext="A R T R"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strain, has the largest relative increase in the <math alttext="I C 50"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IC50</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the information provided about the mouse model, calculate how many times more sensitive the original <math alttext="A R T S"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Plasmodium strain is to artesunate than is the <math alttext="A R T R"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ART-R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strain.

(d) In the mouse model of malaria, the researchers injected Plasmodium-infected human red blood cells into the mice because the Plasmodium species had surface ligand proteins that bound only to cell membrane proteins of human red blood cells. Assume that the researchers noticed that some of the parasites no longer infected human red blood cells but instead infected mouse red blood cells. Predict the most likely cause of this change in the host specificity of the parasites. Plasmodium reproduces both sexually in the host vertebrate and asexually in mosquitoes. The researchers claim that the Plasmodium organisms that infect the two different types of red blood cells are likely to evolve into two separate species of Plasmodium. Based on the biological species concept, provide reasoning that would support the researchers’ claim.
